docs.title: What is This?
docs.text:
Sloppy Wiki is a template repository that shows you how to create beautiful, searchable documentation wikis using MkDocs and the Material for MkDocs theme. It's designed to be forked, customized, and deployed with minimal effort.

This template includes:

🚀 Quick Setup

Three simple scripts to get started: activate, serve, and build

🎨 Beautiful Theme

Material Design with dark mode, search, and mobile support

⚙️ Auto-Deploy

GitHub Actions workflow for automatic deployment to GitHub Pages

📝 Rich Content

Markdown extensions for code blocks, diagrams, admonitions, and more

🔧 Fully Customizable

Easy to modify colors, fonts, navigation, and styling

📚 Well Documented

Every feature explained with examples you can learn from

docs.title: Why Use This Template?
docs.text:
• Learn by Example: Every file is commented and explained

  • Free Hosting: Deploy to GitHub Pages at no cost
  • Fast: Static site generation means blazing-fast load times
  • Searchable: Built-in search functionality out of the box

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
Get your wiki up and running in three commands:

# 1. Clone or fork this repository
git clone https://github.com/pierce403/sloppy-wiki.git
cd sloppy-wiki

# 2. Set up the environment
source activate.sh

# 3. Start the development server
./serve.sh

Your wiki will be available at http://127.0.0.1:8000 with live reloading!

docs.title: What is Mermaid?
docs.text:
Mermaid is a JavaScript library that generates diagrams from text definitions. It's perfect for documentation because:

  • Diagrams are version-controlled as text
  • No need for external diagramming tools
  • Easy to update and maintain
  • Renders beautifully in both light and dark modes

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
Keep It Simple

Don't try to show everything in one diagram. Break complex systems into multiple simpler diagrams.

Use Meaningful Labels

Use clear, descriptive labels for nodes and connections.

Consider Your Audience

Technical diagrams for developers, simple flows for stakeholders.

Browser Rendering

Very complex diagrams may render slowly. If performance is an issue, consider splitting the diagram.

Type Name Value CNAME wiki username.github.io

Type Name Value A @ 185.199.108.153 A @ 185.199.109.153 A @ 185.199.110.153 A @ 185.199.111.153

docs.title: GitHub Pages Deployment
docs.text: Deploy your wiki to GitHub Pages for free hosting.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• GitHub account
  • Repository with your wiki
  • GitHub Actions enabled (default for public repos)

docs.title: Step 1: Push to GitHub
docs.text:
If you haven't already:

git add .
git commit -m "Initial commit"
git push -u origin main

docs.title: Step 2: Enable GitHub Pages
docs.text:
1. Go to your repository on GitHub
  2. Click Settings tab
  3. Click Pages in the left sidebar
  4. Under Source, select: GitHub Actions

docs.title: Step 3: Workflow File
docs.text:
The template includes .github/workflows/deploy.yml which handles deployment automatically.

Verify it exists:

cat .github/workflows/deploy.yml

docs.title: Step 4: Push and Deploy
docs.text:
The workflow triggers automatically on push to main:

git push

Watch the deployment:

  1. Go to Actions tab on GitHub
  2. Watch the "Deploy MkDocs to GitHub Pages" workflow
  3. Wait for the green checkmark ✓

docs.title: Step 5: Access Your Site
docs.text:
Your wiki will be available at:

https://YOUR-USERNAME.github.io/REPOSITORY-NAME

For example: 

https://pierce403.github.io/sloppy-wiki

docs.title: Understanding the Workflow
docs.text:
The .github/workflows/deploy.yml file:

name: Deploy MkDocs to GitHub Pages

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main

permissions:
  contents: read
  pages: write
  id-token: write

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Setup Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v5
        with:
          python-version: '3.11'

      - name: Install dependencies
        run: pip install -r requirements.txt

      - name: Build site
        run: mkdocs build --strict

      - name: Upload artifact
        uses: actions/upload-pages-artifact@v3
        with:
          path: ./site

  deploy:
    environment:
      name: github-pages
      url: ${{ steps.deployment.outputs.page_url }}
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    needs: build
    steps:
      - name: Deploy
        uses: actions/deploy-pages@v4

docs.title: Updating site_url
docs.text:
After deployment, update mkdocs.yml:

site_url: https://YOUR-USERNAME.github.io/REPOSITORY-NAME

Commit and push:

git add mkdocs.yml
git commit -m "Update site_url"
git push

docs.title: Workflow Fails
docs.text:
Check the logs:

  1. Go to Actions tab
  2. Click on the failed workflow run
  3. Expand the failed step to see error details

Common issues:

docs.title: Missing Dependencies
docs.text:
Error: ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'mkdocs'

Solution: Check requirements.txt is present and correct.

docs.title: Build Errors
docs.text:
Error: Config value: 'nav'. Error: ...

Solution: Validate mkdocs.yml locally:

mkdocs build --strict

Fix any errors before pushing.

docs.title: Permission Denied
docs.text:
Error: Resource not accessible by integration

Solution: Enable write permissions in .github/workflows/deploy.yml:

permissions:
  contents: read
  pages: write
  id-token: write

docs.title: Page Not Found (404)
docs.text:
Check these:

  1. Workflow completed successfully

  2. Green checkmark in Actions tab

  3. GitHub Pages is enabled

  4. Settings → Pages → Source: GitHub Actions

  5. Wait a few minutes

  6. First deployment can take 5-10 minutes

  7. Check the URL

  8. Must be: username.github.io/repo-name
  9. Not: username.github.io (unless repo is named username.github.io)

docs.title: Old Content Showing
docs.text:

  • Chrome/Edge: Ctrl+Shift+R (Cmd+Shift+R on Mac)
  • Firefox: Ctrl+Shift+Del
  • Or try incognito/private mode

docs.text:
Check your repository name:

If your repo is named username.github.io: - Site will be at: https://username.github.io

For any other repo name my-wiki: - Site will be at: https://username.github.io/my-wiki

Update mkdocs.yml:

# For username.github.io repository
site_url: https://username.github.io

# For other repositories
site_url: https://username.github.io/repo-name

docs.text: If you prefer not to use GitHub Actions:

docs.text:

docs.title: Option 2: MkDocs Built-in

This builds and pushes to gh-pages branch.

Conflicts with GitHub Actions

If using manual deployment, remove .github/workflows/deploy.yml to avoid conflicts.

docs.title: Private Repositories
docs.text:
GitHub Pages for private repos requires:

  • GitHub Pro, Team, or Enterprise account
  • Or make your repository public

docs.text:
Deploy to staging and production:

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main        # Production
      - staging     # Staging environment

docs.title: View Deployment History
docs.text:
1. Go to Deployments (right sidebar on repo page)
  2. See all deployments with timestamps
  3. Click to view specific deployment logs

Deploy daily at midnight:

  schedule:
    - cron: '0 0 * * *'

docs.title: Manual Trigger
docs.text:
Allow manual workflow runs:

on:
  workflow_dispatch:

Then trigger from Actions tab → Run workflow.

docs.title: Cost
docs.text:
GitHub Pages is:

  • ✅ Free for public repositories
  • ✅ Free for private repos with GitHub Pro/Team/Enterprise
  • ✅ 1GB storage limit
  • ✅ 100GB bandwidth per month
  • ✅ 10 builds per hour

For most wikis, this is more than enough.

docs.text:
The Material theme supports color customization:

theme:
  name: material
  palette:
    # Light mode
    - media: "(prefers-color-scheme: light)"
      scheme: default
      primary: indigo      # Header/accent color
      accent: indigo       # Links and buttons
      toggle:
        icon: material/brightness-7
        name: Switch to dark mode

    # Dark mode
    - media: "(prefers-color-scheme: dark)"
      scheme: slate
      primary: indigo
      accent: indigo
      toggle:
        icon: material/brightness-4
        name: Switch to light mode

    python -c "import yaml; yaml.safe_load(open('mkdocs.yml'))"
  4. Build strictly: mkdocs build --strict

docs.title: YAML Syntax Errors
docs.text:
Common mistakes:

# ❌ Wrong: Missing space after colon
site_name:My Wiki

# ✅ Correct: Space after colon
site_name: My Wiki

# ❌ Wrong: Inconsistent indentation
nav:
  - Home: index.md
    - About: about.md

# ✅ Correct: Consistent indentation
nav:
  - Home: index.md
  - About: about.md

docs.title: Feature Not Working
docs.text:
1. Check if plugin is installed
  2. Verify plugin is listed in plugins: section
  3. Check for typos in feature names
  4. Review plugin documentation for required config

docs.title: First Steps
docs.text: Your environment is set up and running. Now what? This guide walks you through your first customizations.

docs.title: Understanding the Project Structure
docs.text:
sloppy-wiki/
├── docs/                    # All your content goes here
│   ├── index.md            # Homepage
│   ├── css/                # Custom stylesheets
│   ├── img/                # Images and assets
│   └── */                  # Content sections
├── mkdocs.yml              # Main configuration file
├── requirements.txt        # Python dependencies
├── activate.sh             # Environment setup
├── serve.sh                # Development server
├── build.sh                # Build static site
├── .github/workflows/      # CI/CD automation
└── site/                   # Generated output (git-ignored)

docs.title: Step 1: Personalize Site Settings
docs.text:
Open mkdocs.yml and update these basic settings:

site_name: My Knowledge Base           # Your wiki's name
site_description: My personal documentation
site_author: Your Name
site_url: https://yourusername.github.io/my-wiki

repo_name: yourusername/my-wiki
repo_url: https://github.com/yourusername/my-wiki

Save and check http://127.0.0.1:8000 - it updates automatically!

docs.title: Step 2: Customize the Homepage
docs.text:
Edit docs/index.md to create your own welcome page:

# Welcome to My Wiki

This is my personal knowledge base where I document everything I learn.

## What's Inside

- Technical tutorials
- Project documentation
- Personal notes
- Research findings

## Quick Links

- [About Me](about.md)
- [Projects](projects/index.md)
- [Blog](blog/index.md)

docs.title: Step 3: Change the Color Scheme
docs.text:
Edit the theme colors in mkdocs.yml:

theme:
  palette:
    - scheme: default
      primary: teal        # Try: red, blue, green, purple
      accent: cyan         # Highlight color

Color options: red, pink, purple, deep purple, indigo, blue, light blue, cyan, teal, green, light green, lime, yellow, amber, orange, deep orange

docs.title: Step 4: Add Your First Page
docs.text:
Create a new page about yourself:

# Create the file
cat > docs/about.md << 'EOF'
# About Me

Hi! I'm a developer who loves documenting things.

## Background

- Background info here
- More details

## Contact

- Email: your@email.com
- GitHub: @yourusername
EOF

Add it to navigation in mkdocs.yml:

nav:
  - Home: index.md
  - About: about.md

docs.title: Step 5: Add a Logo
docs.text:
Create or download a logo image, then:

  1. Place it in docs/img/logo.png
  2. Update mkdocs.yml:
theme:
  logo: img/logo.png
  favicon: img/logo.png

Logo Recommendations

  • Format: PNG or SVG (SVG preferred)
  • Size: 128x128px or larger
  • Background: Transparent
  • Color: Should contrast with header background

docs.title: Step 6: Organize Your Content
docs.text:
Create sections for different topics:

# Create directory structure
mkdir -p docs/{tutorials,projects,notes}

# Create index pages
echo "# Tutorials" > docs/tutorials/index.md
echo "# Projects" > docs/projects/index.md
echo "# Notes" > docs/notes/index.md

Update navigation:

nav:
  - Home: index.md

  - Tutorials:
    - tutorials/index.md

  - Projects:
    - projects/index.md

  - Notes:
    - notes/index.md

  - About: about.md

docs.title: Step 7: Add Some Content Features
docs.text:
Enable useful Markdown extensions in mkdocs.yml:

markdown_extensions:
  - admonition          # Note/warning boxes
  - pymdownx.highlight  # Code highlighting
  - pymdownx.superfences # Fenced code blocks
  - pymdownx.tasklist:   # Checkboxes
      custom_checkbox: true
  - tables              # Markdown tables

Now you can use these features! See Markdown Tips.

docs.title: Step 8: Test Your Build
docs.text:
Make sure everything builds correctly:

./build.sh

If successful, you'll see: 

INFO    -  Cleaning site directory
INFO    -  Building documentation to directory: /path/to/site
INFO    -  Documentation built in 0.50 seconds
✓ Build complete!

docs.title: Step 9: Commit Your Changes
docs.text:
git add .
git commit -m "Personalize wiki with my information"
git push

docs.title: Step 10: Set Up GitHub Pages
docs.text:
See the Deployment Guide for detailed instructions.

Quick version:

  1. Go to your repository on GitHub
  2. Settings → Pages
  3. Source: GitHub Actions
  4. Push to main branch
  5. Your site will be live at https://yourusername.github.io/repository-name

docs.title: Remove Template Content
docs.text:
Delete example pages you don't need:

rm -rf docs/getting-started
rm -rf docs/examples

Update mkdocs.yml to remove them from navigation.

docs.title: Add a Blog Section
docs.text:
mkdir -p docs/blog
cat > docs/blog/index.md << 'EOF'
# Blog

Recent posts and updates.

## 2025

- [My First Post](2025-01-15-first-post.md)
EOF

docs.title: Create a Projects Portfolio
docs.text:
mkdir -p docs/projects
cat > docs/projects/my-cool-project.md << 'EOF'
# My Cool Project

![Screenshot](../img/project-screenshot.png)

## Overview

Description of your project...

## Features

- Feature 1
- Feature 2

## Links

- [GitHub](https://github.com/user/project)
- [Demo](https://example.com)
EOF

docs.title: Installation Guide
docs.text: Complete installation instructions for all platforms.

docs.title: System Requirements
docs.text:
• Python: 3.8 or higher
  • Git: Latest version recommended
  • Disk Space: ~100MB for dependencies
  • RAM: 512MB minimum (1GB+ recommended)

docs.title: Install Python
docs.text:
Python 3 usually comes pre-installed on macOS. Check your version:

python3 --version

If you need to install or upgrade:

# Using Homebrew (recommended)
brew install python3

# Or download from python.org
# https://www.python.org/downloads/macos/

docs.title: Install Git
docs.text:
# Using Homebrew
brew install git

# Or download from git-scm.com
# https://git-scm.com/download/mac

docs.title: Debian/Ubuntu
docs.text:
# Update package list
sudo apt update

# Install Python 3 and pip
sudo apt install python3 python3-pip python3-venv git

# Verify installation
python3 --version
git --version

docs.title: Fedora/RHEL/CentOS
docs.text:
# Install Python 3 and pip
sudo dnf install python3 python3-pip git

# Verify installation
python3 --version
git --version

docs.title: Arch Linux
docs.text:
# Install Python and Git
sudo pacman -S python python-pip git

# Verify installation
python --version
git --version

docs.title: Install Python
docs.text:
1. Download Python from python.org
  2. Run the installer
  3. Important: Check "Add Python to PATH"
  4. Click "Install Now"

Verify installation in Command Prompt or PowerShell:

python --version
pip --version

docs.title: Install Git
docs.text:
1. Download Git from git-scm.com
  2. Run the installer with default options
  3. Verify installation:
git --version

Windows Users

Consider using Git Bash (included with Git) or Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) for a better command-line experience.

docs.title: Using GitHub (Recommended)
docs.text:
1. Fork the repository on GitHub:
  2. Go to https://github.com/pierce403/sloppy-wiki

  3. Click "Fork" button

  4. Clone your fork: 

    git clone https://github.com/YOUR-USERNAME/sloppy-wiki.git
cd sloppy-wiki

docs.title: Direct Clone
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/pierce403/sloppy-wiki.git
cd sloppy-wiki

docs.title: Automatic Setup (Recommended)
docs.text:
We provide a script that does everything:

source activate.sh

This will: - Create a virtual environment - Activate it - Install all dependencies

docs.title: Manual Setup
docs.text:
If you prefer to do it manually:

# Create virtual environment
python3 -m venv venv

# Activate it
# On macOS/Linux:
source venv/bin/activate
# On Windows:
venv\Scripts\activate

# Upgrade pip
pip install --upgrade pip

# Install dependencies
pip install -r requirements.txt

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
Test that everything works:

# Check MkDocs is installed
mkdocs --version

# Try building the site
mkdocs build

# Start the development server
mkdocs serve

If the server starts successfully, open http://127.0.0.1:8000 in your browser.

docs.title: For Additional Plugins
docs.text:
# Git revision dates
pip install mkdocs-git-revision-date-localized-plugin

# Minification
pip install mkdocs-minify-plugin

# Mermaid diagrams
pip install mkdocs-mermaid2-plugin

Add these to requirements.txt if you want them permanently.

docs.title: VS Code (Recommended)
docs.text:
Install these extensions:

  • Python by Microsoft
  • Markdown All in One by Yu Zhang
  • markdownlint by David Anson
  • YAML by Red Hat

docs.title: PyCharm
docs.text:
1. Open the project directory
  2. PyCharm should auto-detect the virtual environment
  3. Enable Markdown support in Settings → Plugins

docs.title: Vim/Neovim
docs.text:
Install these plugins:

  • vim-markdown for Markdown syntax
  • ale for linting
  • coc-yaml for YAML support

docs.title: "python3: command not found"
docs.text:
• macOS/Linux: Install Python 3 using your package manager
  • Windows: Reinstall Python and check "Add to PATH"

docs.title: "Permission denied" on activate.sh
docs.text:
Make the script executable:

chmod +x activate.sh serve.sh build.sh

docs.title: "pip: command not found"
docs.text:
# macOS/Linux
python3 -m ensurepip --upgrade

# Windows
python -m ensurepip --upgrade

docs.title: Virtual Environment Won't Activate
docs.text:
On Windows with PowerShell:

You may need to enable script execution:

Set-ExecutionPolicy -ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned -Scope CurrentUser

On macOS/Linux:

Make sure you're using source:

source venv/bin/activate  # Correct
./venv/bin/activate       # Wrong!

docs.title: Dependencies Fail to Install
docs.text:
Try upgrading pip first:

pip install --upgrade pip setuptools wheel
pip install -r requirements.txt

docs.title: Port 8000 Already in Use
docs.text:
Use a different port:

mkdocs serve -a 127.0.0.1:8001

docs.title: Upgrading
docs.text:
To update to the latest version of dependencies:

# Activate your environment
source venv/bin/activate

# Upgrade packages
pip install --upgrade -r requirements.txt

To get updates from the template repository:

# Add upstream remote (first time only)
git remote add upstream https://github.com/pierce403/sloppy-wiki.git

# Fetch and merge updates
git fetch upstream
git merge upstream/main

docs.title: Uninstallation
docs.text:
To remove the project:

# Deactivate virtual environment (if active)
deactivate

# Remove the directory
cd ..
rm -rf sloppy-wiki

docs.title: Quick Start Guide
docs.text: Get your wiki up and running in under 5 minutes!

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before you begin, make sure you have:

  • Git installed (download here)
  • Python 3.8+ installed (download here)
  • A GitHub account (for deployment)
  • A text editor (VS Code, Sublime, Vim, etc.)

docs.title: Step 1: Get the Template
docs.text: You have two options:

docs.title: Option A: Fork on GitHub (Recommended)
docs.text:
1. Go to github.com/pierce403/sloppy-wiki
  2. Click the "Fork" button in the top right
  3. Clone your fork:
git clone https://github.com/YOUR-USERNAME/sloppy-wiki.git
cd sloppy-wiki

docs.title: Option B: Clone Directly
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/pierce403/sloppy-wiki.git
cd sloppy-wiki
rm -rf .git  # Remove original git history
git init     # Start fresh

docs.title: Step 2: Set Up Environment
docs.text:
Run the activation script to set up your Python environment:

source activate.sh

This script will:

  • Create a virtual environment (venv/)
  • Activate it
  • Install all required dependencies
  • Give you next-step instructions

Virtual Environment

The activate.sh script creates an isolated Python environment. You'll need to activate it each time you open a new terminal: 

source venv/bin/activate

docs.title: Step 3: Start the Development Server
docs.text:
./serve.sh

Your wiki will be available at http://127.0.0.1:8000

The server includes live reload - any changes you make to files will automatically refresh in your browser!

You're Running!

Open http://127.0.0.1:8000 and you should see this wiki template.

docs.title: Update Site Information
docs.text:
Edit mkdocs.yml and change:

site_name: Sloppy Wiki Template  # Change this!
site_description: Your wiki description
site_author: Your Name Here
site_url: https://yourusername.github.io/your-wiki

docs.title: Modify the Homepage
docs.text: Edit docs/index.md to create your own landing page.

docs.title: Add Your First Page
docs.text:
1. Create a new markdown file in docs/: 

    echo "# My First Page" > docs/my-first-page.md

  2. Add it to the navigation in mkdocs.yml: 

    nav:
  - Home: index.md
  - My First Page: my-first-page.md

  3. The page will automatically reload in your browser!

docs.title: Step 5: Build Your Site
docs.text:
When you're ready to see the final output:

./build.sh

This generates static HTML in the site/ directory.

Testing the Build

You can test the built site locally: 

cd site
python -m http.server 8000

docs.text:

Quick version:

  1. Push your changes to GitHub
  2. The site will automatically deploy via GitHub Actions
  3. Access it at https://yourusername.github.io/repository-name
